328aad24-98f6-4d5e-93f6-76c9be21a4bc.description: Upon completion of the five-week training, earner has met requirements for campus placement and has demonstrated the ability to network with other staff members, students and donors. Earner has a high capacity for moral integrity and has achieved proficiency as a team player.
328aad24-98f6-4d5e-93f6-76c9be21a4bc.name: Year 1: New Staff Training (NST)

badge_template_activities.title: Earner attends five weeks of educational training followed by an additional six weeks of ongoing professional development experience. Training includes elements of human, spiritual, intellectual and apostolic formation.

Classes cover topics such as classical anthropology, Church teaching, history of philosophical movements in America, non-profit development techniques, outreach/evangelization practicals, mental health, professional boundaries, spiritual practices and interpersonal relationships.
During training, earner participates in daily prayer, regular mentorship and small-group discussion of classroom content.
While at New Staff Training, earner consistently demonstrates uprightness of character and passes continuous evaluation by small-group leaders and managers.

3bf67da9-48bd-43a1-9ffc-e396e4b0a760.description: After completing their first year on staff, earner has completed their second five-week summer training. Earner has learned how to deepen relationships with other staff, students and donors. Earner has achieved a high capacity for moral integrity and has achieved proficiency as a team player.
3bf67da9-48bd-43a1-9ffc-e396e4b0a760.name: Year 2: New Staff Training (NST)

badge_template_activities.title: Earner attends their second five-week educational training followed by an additional six weeks of ongoing professional development experience. Training includes elements of human, spiritual, intellectual and apostolic formation.

Classes cover topics such as classical anthropology, Church teaching, history of philosophical movements in America, non-profit development techniques, outreach/evangelization practicals, mental health, professional boundaries, spiritual practices and interpersonal relationships.
During training, earner participates in daily prayer, regular mentorship and small-group discussion of classroom content.
While at New Staff Training, earner consistently demonstrates uprightness of character and passes continuous evaluation by small-group leaders and managers.

4a3abf86-dcaa-4dfb-9b34-5f73868b2dc9.description: Once a missionary reaches $3,260 in monthly support, they are considered fully-funded and also have potential to reach the highest marks on annual reviews. Missionaries who do not reach minimum fundraising requirements cannot be placed on campus or at the Denver Support Center.
4a3abf86-dcaa-4dfb-9b34-5f73868b2dc9.name: Fundraising Milestone: Achieved Level 1 Fundraising Goal

badge_template_activities.title: Attended SRS Bootcamp, a 3-day training on vision and practicals of fundraising a missionary support team. Brainstormed and brought a list of potential donors.
Called potential donors, set up appointments, presented the Mission, and made asks on a sliding scale.
The earner of this badge raised and maintained recurring financial support of $3260 monthly. Followed-up with donors via thank you card, text, and/or call.

skills.name: Ability To Build And Develop Professional Relationships

64a32d42-7964-4c4d-82f5-b34063ea92e9.description: Upon completion of a successful domestic or international mission trip through FOCUS, earner has recruited, fundraise-coached, and led small group experiences for 1-3 weeks in impoverished areas. Mission Trip Leaders are part of a support staff team, helping the Mission Trip Director (Level 2) execute tasks needed for a successful trip. This is an optional leadership role that missionary staff can take to further their apostolate.
64a32d42-7964-4c4d-82f5-b34063ea92e9.name: Level 1: Mission Trip Leader

badge_template_activities.title: Once accepted to the position, Mission Trip Leader recruits participants from their campus or community. Leader is expected to recruit at least one student from their campus to keep their spot for mission.

Leader coaches participants to fundraise the total cost of the mission trip throughout the months leading up to trip departure. Fundraise coaching includes vision casting, regular phone calls, and encouragement. Leader also holds participants accountable to time-bound goals for fundraising levels.

Along with completing logistical tasks given to them by the Mission Trip Director, earner must attend weekly team meetings for six to nine months before the trip to ensure all details and tasks are brought to completion.

Once the trip departs, the group serves marginalized populations by collaborating with local organizations to ensure help is being given where it is most needed. Leader helps form participants through a series of assigned talks, and they check-in regularly with the Mission Trip Director to ensure trip quality and group safety. Leader contributes to the general well-being of trip participants by continued coaching throughout the duration of the trip.

de6ba52f-c240-49c9-a17e-cfaca6a5db8f.description: By attending an in-house training that applies Topgrading methodology for improving the productivity, profitability, and progress of an organization, earner is qualified to conduct departmental interviews for FOCUS.
de6ba52f-c240-49c9-a17e-cfaca6a5db8f.name: Level 2: Topgrading Trained Interviewer

badge_template_activities.title: Staff member attended interview training using Topgrading methodology led by a member of Talent and Leadership Development.
Earner has capacity to conduct departmental interviews, identify strengths and cautions in applicants, advise decision makers, and select new members of their team.

72789499-e51a-40af-ac13-38a50d695d7a.description: Earner of this badge has been selected to lead, onboard and form new staff. This leader has achieved a level of character and a high level of success in their role to be a model for new staff members. Earner is a mature communicator who can walk with new staff member in the initial stages of employment with FOCUS.
72789499-e51a-40af-ac13-38a50d695d7a.name: Level 3: New Staff Training (NST) - Trainer

badge_template_activities.title: Earner accompanies about 10 new staff members through formation and training classes, facilitates small group discussion after each class and formally evaluates new staff. As a result, the earner ensures new staff members adequately understand the training content and develop good habits to prepare for work on campus.
Earner is recommended by regional leadership to be a key trainer for new staff and receives three days of additional leadership training.
Earner gives professional feedback to each of their small group of new staff members and records further professional growth areas for each staff member.

fe48fb2d-2dca-4dba-904b-67e2a59ff99d.description: Upon completion of a successful domestic or international mission trip through FOCUS, earners have recruited, organized, and directed trips for 1-3 weeks in impoverished areas. Mission Trip Directors are the lead organizer of a mission trip, working with a FOCUS Missions Coach and Mission Trip Leaders (Level 1) to coordinate and execute a successful mission trip. This is an optional leadership role that FOCUS staff can take on to further their professional development and leadership.
fe48fb2d-2dca-4dba-904b-67e2a59ff99d.name: Level 2: Mission Trip Director

badge_template_activities.title: To qualify as a Mission Trip Director, the earner must have previously served on a FOCUS Mission Trip team as a Leader (Level 1) and must have received a recommendation by their previous trip's Director.
Mission Trip Director is responsible for setting goals with members of their team to recruit participants for the mission trip, with at least one participant coming from their campus.

Mission Trip Director coaches teammates and participants to fundraise the entire cost of their trip through personal invitations. Each trip participant is required to meet minimum standards of fundraising before allowance onto the trip. Director helps establish the trip's budget and is responsible for expenses throughout the duration of the trip.
Mission Trip Director sets and facilitates weekly team meetings for six to nine months before the trip to check-in on recruitment, student fundraising, and other logistical tasks.

Mission Trip Director is required to attend a training called Mission Director Leadership Summit (MDLS). MDLS is a week-long training wherein Mission Trip Directors learn international and domestic travel practices, risk mitigation techniques, emergency training, diplomacy, and the learning arc of trip participants. In addition, they learn how to properly interact with third-party hosts, manage a group, and facilitate transformative experiences.

Once the trip departs, the group serves marginalized populations by collaborating with local organizations to ensure help is being given where it is most needed. The Mission Trip Director coordinates ongoing check-in's with Mission Trip Leaders and forms participants through a series of assigned talks. Mission Trip Directors contribute to the success of the trip through their leadership and purview of participant experiences.
Mission Trip Directors and Leaders facilitate a debriefing session at the conclusion of the trip to help participants process their experience.

dd4d9c2b-9569-489c-87f8-edc0e0c81f92.description: Upon completion of new campus manager training, known as Team Director Training, earner has capacity and approval to lead a team of at least three missionaries at a college, university, or parish. Director is responsible for the success of campus program, maintaining relationship with local chaplain and diocese, ongoing coaching and evaluation of teammates, and execution of reports and campus budget. Earner has consistently demonstrated character and skills needed for leadership.
dd4d9c2b-9569-489c-87f8-edc0e0c81f92.name: Advanced Leadership Training: New Campus Manager Training

badge_template_activities.title: Earner has demonstrated capacity for professionalism, work ethic, and success in current campus missionary role. In qualification interview, earner is evaluated on metrics and elements pertaining to role. Leadership capacity is assessed at this time.

Team-Director-Qualified (TDQ) candidates may or may not be placed as a campus manager for the next school year. TDQ candidates may be asked to commit for multiple years at the same location before placement.

Earners attend a week-long immersive leadership training wherein they are taught skills like conflict management, ethical leadership, communication, developmental assessment, and coaching. Supplemental leadership skills training continues throughout the year.

49b611eb-d37d-4f47-ab1b-0efd0d13bb1a.description: Earner completed FOCUS's manager training, known as Servant Leadership Foundations, and are primed for promotion to the level of management. Rising leaders are committed to growing their capacity to live out FOCUS's key leadership competencies in human, technical, and conceptual areas. Key competencies for FOCUS managers include clear strategic vision and execution, communication, strong team building, care for the whole person, and prudent decision making.
49b611eb-d37d-4f47-ab1b-0efd0d13bb1a.name: Leadership Training: Servant Leadership Foundations

badge_template_activities.title: Earner had been recommended by department head to attend Servante Leadership Foundations training. Criteria for recommendation include current success in role, possibility of promotion, personal fundraising achievement, and professionalism.

Earner has attended up to two three-day classroom trainings in-person. Throughout training, classes include concepts like crucial conversations, effective listening, mindset, team-building, coaching, and delegation.
Upon completion of material, earner has gained capacity for higher levels of leadership and management. Special emphasis in classes is placed on communication and strategic vision and execution.

5c3ae1cc-81fd-4255-989b-bfa04b7f9ffe.description: Earners are eligible to continue working for FOCUS' administrative departments once they complete a one-year training called the Fellowship Program. Built on three pillars of Community, Career Development, and Professional Formation; Fellows receive year-long training to succeed in their new roles.
5c3ae1cc-81fd-4255-989b-bfa04b7f9ffe.name: Advanced Leadership Training: Fellowship Program for Professional Development

badge_template_activities.title: After working as a campus missionary for at least two years, Fellows applied and were accepted into the Fellowship program by a specific department in FOCUS. Each Fellow must meet minimum requirements for annual fundraising goals and demonstrate professionalism, timeliness, and responsibility.
Fellows attend semi-monthly classes, participate in regular small-group discussion, and may elect additional opportunities such as mentorship and productivity resources.
Fellows are asked to complete a curriculum of relevant business and spiritual reading and to discuss their thoughts with an assigned small group.
Mid-year and end-of-year reviews track Fellows' progress and determine whether they are eligible to continue their employment with FOCUS.

47d6faa0-8520-4745-989a-0ea73d3a1ea6.description: Upon completion of this Level 2 badge, earner has support-raised beyond the 10:7 Wage (which is $3,260 in monthly support.) Depending on state life and other circumstances, the 10:7 Wage may be insufficient for maximizing the fruitfulness of a missionary's ministry and vocation. Earner has shown initiative and perseverance to reach goals beyond minimum requirements set by organization.
47d6faa0-8520-4745-989a-0ea73d3a1ea6.name: Fundraising Milestone: Achieved Level 2 Fundraising Goal

badge_template_activities.title: Recurring MPD support at or above a missionary's "14:28 Wage." Each missionary determines the exact 14:28 number based on state in life, monthly expenses, and mission-related projects.
Monthly or non-monthly recurring donations broken up into monthly equivalent must be at or above $3260 monthly for a period of 3 months.
From the support team already built, earner utilized the same skills developed during initial fundraising efforts to expand their support team account to a level that can sustain their state in life.

skills.name: Ability To Build And Develop Professional Relationships

035df883-2293-489d-8db3-7ea7659e0cda.description: Prayer Team Member has learned the theological foundations of intercessory prayer based on FOCUS's 12 prudential guidelines for praying with others. Prayer team member has also received teaching on healing, spiritual warfare, and spiritual authority, and practicals of how to implement these teachings in a prayer team setting.
035df883-2293-489d-8db3-7ea7659e0cda.name: Leadership Training: Prayer Team Member

badge_template_activities.title: Participant must complete the "Praying with Others" online training. Training includes methods of prayer and discerning proper boundaries when praying with others.

Participant must agree to follow the FOCUS Guidelines for "Praying with Others." For example, guidelines include proper boundaries between men and women, proper conduct in the case mental health situations are brought forth, and the prayer model of Ask, Listen, Love, and Pray.

4a55273d-fd65-4c8c-af25-5e32a483eec2.description: By participating in this training, earner has demonstrated ability to design effective curriculum for adult audiences based on best practices for adult learning. Participants in this training design curriculum to engage learners through hands-on activities. In order to participate in training, earner was recommended by department heads and invited based on public speaking ability, opportunities to teach in the future, and success in current role.
4a55273d-fd65-4c8c-af25-5e32a483eec2.name: Leadership Training: Teach The Teacher

badge_template_activities.title: Earner completes three days of training on adult learning techniques that concludes with a presentation to panel of judges.
In the final presentation, earner selects a topic and designs a learning activity to teach the entire group of participants. Feedback and correction are given by panel and peers.

9c1a9553-c5b9-412d-b06a-46ecf7b94efc.description: Upon completion of the National Conference or Annual Staff Training hosted by FOCUS, earner has the ability to demonstrate critical thinking skills to execute high level tasks in a fast-paced environment. Committee Member is part of a support staff team, helping the Committee Head execute tasks needed for a successful event. This is an optional leadership role that missionary staff can take to further their leadership development and apostolate.
9c1a9553-c5b9-412d-b06a-46ecf7b94efc.name: Level 1: Events Committee Member

badge_template_activities.title: Once accepted to the position, Committee Member is responsible for managing specific tasks within a project area to ensure the success of the overall event. This is typically a 3 to 5 hour additional weekly commitment to daily responsibilities.

Committee Member attends customer service training, learning how to be a great representative of the FOCUS and FOCUS Conference brand by helping attendees with any issues they may encounter leading up to or onsite at the event.

Committee Member must attend weekly team meetings for six months before the event to ensure all details and tasks are being brought to completion. Many tasks include coordinating with external vendors and/or VIP guests in a professional manner.

Onsite Committee Member works together to execute all plans within their project area. Committee Member also exercises great flexibility by addressing areas of additional need and collaborating with all the other branches of the committee structure. Committee Member is given ownership to update leadership on the projects in real time and elevate the need for greater support as required.

Onsite Committee Member is challenged to balance their role as a missionary and their project workload. They can delegate responsibilities to their students to step into their own leadership of their community in the case Committee Member needs to step away.

1c285a3d-14ec-417b-b463-dcdd0e83a341.description: Upon completion of both in-house interviewer training and the execution of Recruitment Weekend interviews, earner is qualified as a Recruitment Weekend Interviewer.
1c285a3d-14ec-417b-b463-dcdd0e83a341.name: Level 1: Recruitment Weekend - Trained Interviewer

badge_template_activities.title: Interviewer is expected to complete all assigned courses, videos, and in-person training assigned by Recruitment Manger.
Interviewer must assigned interview(s) of applicants to be considered a trained interviewer. Interviewer is part of an organizational effort that hires and onboards 200+ staff members each year.
Interviewer participates in a full deliberation session with other trained interviewers in order to make recommendations for job offer to hiring managers.

8f582b60-3e6f-4ef8-b52f-9457463cb571.description: Upon completion of a retreat, Retreat Leader has assisted the Retreat Director in planning and executing a weekend retreat for 20-100+ participants. During the retreat, the Retreat Leader took on roles such as a speaker, emcee, sacristan, or administrator. This is an optional leadership role that missionary staff can take to further their apostolate and development.
8f582b60-3e6f-4ef8-b52f-9457463cb571.name: Level 1: Retreats Leader

badge_template_activities.title: Retreat Leader takes on roles such a speaker, sacristan, emcee, musician, or administrator during the retreat.
Retreat Leader receives instructions from their Director in the weeks leading up to the retreat and executes 3-12 hours of preparatory work.
Retreat Leader heads recruitment efforts for their campus for multi-campus retreats, coordinating invitation, registration, and payment collection.
Retreat Leader supports the Retreat Director in providing feedback to the FOCUS Retreat Team through a feedback system and completes any follow-up accounting tasks.

9966c87e-c2fe-4968-b856-a16239d04f90.description: Upon completion of FOCUS Summer Projects, earner served as a mentor in both professional and personal skills including management, project management, and sales. Summer Projects is a 10-week program that requires Leaders to dedicate months of preparation time prior to the program. This is an optional leadership role that missionary staff can take to further their leadership development and apostolate. Personal skills including leadership in small-group settings and conflict resolution.
9966c87e-c2fe-4968-b856-a16239d04f90.name: Level 1: Summer Projects Leader

badge_template_activities.title: Summer Projects Leader mentors a small group of 8-12 college students through their experience of a summer internship.
Summer Projects Leader participates in an intensive training designed to prepare them to coach college students to grow in professionalism and leadership.
Summer Projects Leader regularly (at least 5x per week for 10 weeks) presents to small groups of college students.

2bf3fc75-0072-48f7-bdb7-c56089d6d744.description: Upon completion of the National Conference or Annual Staff Training hosted by FOCUS, earner has lead a team by demonstrating critical thinking skills and delegating tasks for execution in a fast-paced environment. Each Committee Head is the lead organizer of a specific project area within the conference or training, working directly with an Events Department Coach. This is an optional leadership role that mission staff can take to further their leadership development and apostolate.
2bf3fc75-0072-48f7-bdb7-c56089d6d744.name: Level 2: Events Committee Head

badge_template_activities.title: To qualify as Committee Head, the earner must have previously served on a FOCUS committee for either SEEK or New Staff Training and/or be an experienced veteran staff member with recommendation from their manager. This is typically a 5 hour additional weekly commitment to daily responsibilities.

Committee Head is given ownership to delegate, coach, and motivate teammates to accomplish the tasks within their project areas. Committee Head determines and assigns deadlines across those working within that project scope. They are also responsible for tracking expenses throughout the planning and onsite process.

Committee Head sets and facilitates weekly team meetings for six months before the event trip to check-in on deadlines and completion of logistical tasks. Earner must exhibit professional communication with many outside vendors or VIP guests.

As part of training, earner attends customer service training and ensures their team attends as well. At this training, Committee Head learns how to be a great representative of the FOCUS/Conference brand in helping attendees with any issues they may encounter leading up to or onsite at the event.

The onsite Committee Head is in charge of ensuring the success of their project area. They also act as a leader who encourages their team in the required flexibility needed and jumps into areas of additional help. Committee Head often communicates directly with vendors and/or VIP guests onsite. They are entrusted to update Events Department Leadership on the projects in real time and elevate the need for greater support as required.

Onsite Committee Head is challenged to balance their role as a missionary and their project workload at Conference/Training. They can delegate responsibilities to their students to step into their own leadership of their community in the case Committee Head needs to step away. They are also given the challenge to care for their teams and ensure they are adequately handling the stress of the fast-paced environment.
Committee Head helps speak into post event debriefs, including future innovations and opportunities for improvement.

skills.name: Maintaining Composure in High Stress Environment

00732f32-c011-49fc-808a-dab6ea69f7d5.description: Retreat Director has planned and executed a weekend retreat for 20-100+ attendees, working alongside a national retreat coach and a leading a team of 2-5 retreat leaders. Primary responsibilities include recruiting participants, working with venue, coordinating the retreat schedule and budget, overseeing excellent delivery of the retreat content, and coaching their retreat team. This is an optional leadership role that missionary staff can take to further their professional development.
00732f32-c011-49fc-808a-dab6ea69f7d5.name: Level 2: Retreats Director

badge_template_activities.title: The Retreat Director coaches the Retreat Team in planning logistics for the retreat and in the Leaders' specific roles. In addition, the Retreat Director selects and leads the prayer team and directs schedule during the retreat.
The Retreat Director delivers 1-2 retreat presentations, specifically the presentations that require a deeper level of knowledge (e.g. talks on healing or spiritual gifts).

Earner attends a Retreat Director training hosted by the National Retreats Team. This 3-day training prepares Retreat Director on how to direct a retreat, work with venues and chaplains, and lead prayer teams. Topics include public speaking, intercessory prayer, spiritual healing, and deliverance/spiritual warfare.
The Retreat Director leads recruitment efforts and takes ownership of the retreat schedule.
The Retreat Director manages the budget and expenses of the retreat.

2f012043-8d2d-4c6a-919c-cfea0d935771.description: Upon completion of FOCUS Summer Projects, earner has managed a $150-300K budget and lead a group of 60-150 people through a difficult and immersive education program. Directors take on 3-5 Leaders (Level 1) as direct reports. Summer Projects is a 10-week program that requires Directors to dedicate months of preparation time prior to the program. This is an optional leadership role that missionary staff can take to further their leadership development and apostolate.
2f012043-8d2d-4c6a-919c-cfea0d935771.name: Level 2: Summer Projects Director

badge_template_activities.title: Successful leadership at a Summer Project involves a demanding set of responsibilities including financial management, professional diplomacy, and team management. Director must not only possess a high degree of professional competence, they must also become experts in managing and developing relationships.
Director educates students directly and they coordinate an immersive educational experience for a large group of college students.
Summer Projects Director regularly (at least 5x per week for 10 weeks) presents to small groups and large groups of college students and Leaders, providing technical and vision-level direction.

a9fdad58-26b1-4c83-bdfb-251baadfb6d0.description: Earner completed the first 12 months of the 36-month leadership development program. The program combines spiritual and practical leadership development training for the Team Director role, including immersion training, lectures, and small groups on a monthly basis. Earner completed coursework while performing everyday duties of leading their teams to drive effectiveness in campus ministry work.
a9fdad58-26b1-4c83-bdfb-251baadfb6d0.name: Year 1: Leadership Fundamentals: Team Director Fellowship Program

badge_template_activities.title: Earner attends a week-long leadership training focusing on servant leadership content such as mindset, crucial conversations, coaching, management, and strategic planning. In addition, earner reads leadership books in conjunction with ongoing classes to better practice and influence habits.
Earner attends formation classes and has at least an 80% attendance rate. Classes include lecture and small group discussion time to establish a goal for a new habit or change in behavior.
After each monthly training session, earner constructs and implements a plan practice or implement a new habit or skill.
